name: Mecha Ace
description: Step into the cockpit of a giant "mecha" robot, dueling with plasma sabers in an interstellar civil war!

reviews.review_text: When I first heard about Choice of Games I kinda laughed at them.   'A CYOA game? Without pictures? At this age?'  I must humbly say how wrong I was.  I tried this game, and had so much fun with it.  Try one of their game. It costs only as much as a burger, and lasts much longer.
Beat an enemy ace in straight up combat, twice.  Lost my hand.  Stopped a war.  CYOA awesomeness at its finest. Only for those who like reading, though.
-Got Kidnapped -Started a gay relationship with a Japanese guy   (who may be underage?... hmm... not sure on that one)   -Killed a traitorous B**** -Saved the Galaxy
Very fun game in the CYOA genre, I highly recommend it for all fans of mecha anime. It does get a bit old though after a few run throughs.

This is one of the best interactive experiences i've ever had. Your choices matter, they have a gravitas in them that similar 'choice games' such as Mass Effect lack, and it's LONG. You'll want to replay the heck out of it trying to get different endings. Love it! I honestly hope they do a sequel, or at least another story in the same genre.
I had 69 confirmed kills by the end of the first chapter.

Mecha Ace is a choose your own adventure e-book, which reads a lot like a decently written Gundam fan-fiction story. There are also character stats, which increase or decrease based on the decisions you make through out the game. If this sounds like something you're interested in, then I'd say definitely give Mecha Ace a shot. I've never played a CYOAB before, but my love of mecha anime seriously made me enjoy the time I've spent so far on this little gem.

I'm going to have to agree with what a lot of other people said in terms of irrelevant choices. While playing this game, it felt as if I wasn't really in control or influencing the story aside from small details. A lot of the time it seemed as if the game did not approve of my choices i.e 'what would you like to do?' *picks option* 'Unfortunately since you did not pick (insert option here), you didn't (insert possible outcome of option you did not pick).' I wasted a lot of time restarting from checkpoints trying to get better outcomes because I was essentially told I could have done it a certain way and gotten a better result. Situations such as these made me feel as if there was some ideal story the author wanted me to follow instead of being free to choose my own, which was counterintuitive to why I bought the game.   Most of the choices made only have the consequence of effecting a 'stat' such as how diplomatic you are or how much will you have. these choices only matter at critical points in the story and very few other times. I will admit the story started to bore me towards the end, but maybe that's just me. I bought the game expecting a lot more combat and actual fighting than exposition and unfortunately that's not what I got (my kill count by the end was somewhere around 73 but 63 of those kills were given to me at the start of the game as background). While it may seem like I am being harsh, I did enjoy the game and you can't beat the price so I reccomend it.

God damn this game is difficult. I mean that the choices are extremely hard to make and what they will lead to is hard to determine, every choice means something and you can't just go back on it without suffering some losses. And that is a good thing. Sometimes with Choice of Games's games I can just rn through them and easily find the best scenario ending, but this one, gosh, I haven't I even finished it because I don't have the heart to see everything crumble around me and not go my way. This game gives a good dose of cold, hard reality and that gives it heart.

First reason to buy, it has an amazingly well written plot. Secondly it will give you real emotional attatchments to some of the characters! And thirdly this is perhapes one of the best CYOA I have played!  10/10 Will fight this war again!
I very much enjoyed playing this game. It felt like I was really in my own Gundam style universe! I look forward to the other interactive novels made by Choice Games.
